First off, excellent video(s) - a veritable work of art!
A question though, as I'm resistant to accepting any result with 100% confidence: let's assume that vortex direction is in fact random. What was the probability of observing these results by chance? Is it 0.5 * 0.5 = 0.25? Or is it somewhere closer to 50-50, since Destin is less likely to have done his half of the experiment without Derek's initial success?

Very cool video! But I have to pour water into the wine. The two pools are obviously not identical. So it is very probable that the effect comes from tiny differences in the construction, e.g. from an eccentricity of the drain hole. Also, the assumption that the water is still after 24 hours is not valid. An open surface water is always in motion of thermal convection, driven by evaporation cooling.
Let's do a simple calculation: The Coriolis acceleration is a = -2 omega v. Omega is the angle velocity of the Earth's rotation 7*10^-5 s^-1. v is the radial flow velocity of the water at the surface, which is extremely small, say 1 cm/s. Taking into account the degree of latitudes of the both places, we get a Coriolis acceleration of the order of some 10^-7 m/s². This means that the time for one revolution of the vortex is of the order of hours. No, the Coriolis effect is way too small for this experiment.

I understand it as your relative position/your point of view comes into play. Take a baseball or a tennis ball and trace a counter clockwise circular line around until you get to the other side of the ball, do not lift your marker. From the starting point you were drawing from is counter clockwise. But when you continue this line seen from the bottom side, you will be moving your pen in a clockwise direction. Now follow your marker line, starting from the bottom side to the top side and it will be perceived in reverse. So I would think that the water drains the same way, its just that you are looking at it from each respective drain sides. Its all relativity as Einstein said. If I may further confuse...when you stand in front of your mirror and raise your right hand, picture yourself standing in the mirror and you will see that you/in the mirror are raising your left hand, not your right. Your relative perspective is very important to understand this. The mirror image says the opposite of what is actually happening and yet it is the same thing. spooky action.
this ws epic

Coriolis effect  is an issue in aviation too.... most aircraft do not use compass but a DI (direction Indicator) or in  the US called a HI (heading indicator) that is based on a gyroscope set in the yaw plane, this is because of the effects of banking, accelerating etc on a compass... however over a period of flight the gyroscope starts to drift because of Coriolis effect (and imperfections in the instrument)... therefore pilots need to re-align their DI/HI every so often to correct for it - this is done by setting to the magnetic compass when in a stable, level flight position. There is nothing definitive about this video - total misapplication of the Coriolis Effect. The Earth's slow rotation and extremely minute distance between opposite ends of such as small-scale pool experiment relative to the earth's curvature means barring surface irregularities in the pool floor and the drain, and the leveling of the pool floor, the initial spin direction is nigh random. One experiment iteration per hemisphere is not what I'd call scientifically-sound testing, and particular galling since of them is a PhD. SMH. The fact that it's the first "Internet demonstration" doesn't invalidate all previous experiments. I just got Dumber by One Day.

There isn't a single instrument on earth that can sense the rotating earth. That a proven fact that has stood the test of time. The water takes the path of least resistance, water going down the drain will continue in the direction it starts in.
I would suggest the effect is caused by something other than the spin of the earth such as a static charge that bends water coming out of a faucet. If you could find a scientific instrument or experiment that could repeatedly prove the earth is moving to go along with this drain test I might consider changing my mind about it, but no instrumentation can or has ever so far.

Although this is an interesting channel, the author needs to brush up on the 'scientific method'.

Crazy stuff that's definitely not worth a subscription to him or that other guy:

He shows that toilets get water swirling in a particular direction with a little jet of water. But there is also the case (shown in his buddy's video) where 2 sinks sitting beside each other drain in opposite directions. So it's the small, initial conditions that matter. Not your location on earth. He should have done 3 more experiments (each done in the north, in the south and at the equator) to convince himself (and the other guy) that this is true:

1. Give the pool a small swirling "clock-wise" motion by hand - at the beginning.
2. Give the pool a small swirling "counter-clock-wise" motion by hand - at the beginning.
3. See if the rotation slows down or even reverses at any location.

So, 2 things may be true at the same time. Water (and air) does preferentially rotate differently in the 2 hemispheres. But, given a small initial "kick" - water (at least) will rotate in the direction you start it in - and will not slow down or even reverse direction - given enough time.
What if you did this experiment directly on the equator. What would be the results then.
Fun fact,  if it wasn’t for all the changes in direction in your plumbing, your faucet water would also spin.

Colocando una cubeta de agua tan solo unos centímetros respecto de la línea ecuatorial, y destapando por abajo de la misma,  el agua gira en un sentido, colocándolo exactamente  a la mitad, no gira simñlemente se drena linealmente y del lado del hemisferio sur unos centímetros gira en sentido contrario a la del hemisferio norte (no recuerdo ahora que sentido era cada hemisferio), pero si recuerdo haber visto las pruebas de este fenómeno. Esto mismo se debería de poder repetir en toda la línea ecuatorial. Conclusión,  no hace falta irse a EE. UU. We KNOW the Coriolis effect is real, this didn't actually prove it. And, you might have eliminated SOME variables, but you didn't get ALL of them. You cannot guarantee that the shape of the kiddie pools are the same on both sides of the planet. You'd need a solid, un-moving container for that, and one that has been verified to be the same for both of you.

That's not to say that I think the experiment is wrong, just that you cannot state with certainty that it's right.

Another fun part about the Coriolis effect on hurricanes is that hurricanes cannot cross the equator without being ripped apart by the Coriolis effect. It’s actually pretty cool, since the Coriolis effect effectively repels hurricanes from the equator, when you look at a map of all the recorded hurricanes in the past 30 or so years, you’ll notice, none of them EVER cross a particular latitude. I'm a plumber in Florida. In the 1980's, a nation wide home-supply store purchasing agent found a great deal on virus-china toilet bowl & tank combinations he could purchase by the train-car load very cheaply and sell them across North America.
Problem...The bowl was fabricated in Brazil. The bowls spin the other way down there. Eventually, after conducting a service call for "toilet not flushing", I finally noticed the spin was the wrong direction. That toilet spin would stop in the middle of the flush cycle, and the tank would be nearly empty before the spin began to move correctly. By then, there wasn't enough water in the tank to lift the fluid over the trap inside the preformed bowl.
I found the label on the back of the bowl marked "Brazil", and realized what the problem was.
After that, for the next year, every time I got a customer-call about "toilet doesn't flush", I'd have the caller look for the name. If they said "Yes", I'd tell them to go back to the store for a replacement and a credit invoice, and I would install it for them. If not, I knew they needed my help for an as yet undetermined malfunction.
I remember the store was magnanimous in supplying the replacement bowl and paying labor for every change-out I did for the following several months. It's truly sad they went out of business soon after, but I doubt that had a connection to the money they lost on the toilets.
Incidentally, I'm one plumbing company out of 100 in this beach area along the Florida west coast. I had 50 of those toilet calls in the first year. Can you imagine how many plumbers struggled over that anomaly for that year before the store removed them from the shelves?

Actually there is no guarantee that drains will run counterclockwise in the northern hemisphere.  Even a kiddie pool might not be a good experiment.  If you did it 100 times, you might get the opposite effect some of the time.  They are rare but some tornadoes have been observed rotating clockwise, even though the vast majority spin counterclockwise.  But with large scale weather systems, such as hurricanes and areas of low pressure ALWAYS turn counterclockwise.  (Rising air)   High pressure systems ALWAYS turn clockwise. (Sinking air)  In the southern hemisphere the opposite is true.  This is caused by the Earth's rotation from west to east.

LOVE your experiments and how well you do everything, with so much care and attention to detail  HOWEVER, this was not at all definitive, nor good experimental validation.  For it to be definitive, you need to repeat that experiment multiple times (let's say 10 times or whatever x-sigma level would be appropriate), to ensure that it wasn't random.  Doing this once at a given location and observing it going one way or another means nothing definitive, because it has to go one way or another even if it was random.  To determine this even more definitively, you should do it at several latitudes on both sides of the equator, measuring rates of rotation as a function of time.

No they do not rotate in different directions.  All that has happened is that you have looked at the same thing from a different point of view.  Imagine this:  You hold an open an faced clock in your hands. The second hand extends past the circumference of the face, it rotates clockwise.  Now you turn the clock around so you see the back of it.  The hand appears to rotate counter-clockwise.  But it has always rotated in the same direction!  Now imagine this.  On the North Pole and the South Pole are two circular swimming pools with a plug for drainage in the center.  You stand above the earth at a point directly above the North Pole.  Because the Earth rotates in the same direction the swirl will be the same.  Looked at from the other direction ie 'below' the South Pole they will appear to rotate in the opposite direction, but the swirl in the North Pool and in the South Pool will be rotating in the same direction - the same direction as when you looked from above the North Pole.

I experienced the change in flow rotation direction in real life. I went to the galapagos, but first stopped in Ecuador, where I went to the equator. The tour had a portable sink with him that had a removable plug in the bottom of it. He put the plug in, filled it up with water, and moved it perhaps a yard to the left of the equator. As the water drained, it spun clockwise. After it drained, he filled it back up and moved it one yard to the RIGHT of the equator. Sure enough, the water spun counterclockwise. But that's not the best part. He then filled it back up and drained it right on top of the equator. This time, when the water drained, it didn't spin AT ALL. It was really incredible!

Great concept, great video, think you got the right answer for the setup you have, but . . . .to get a confident result that you both didn't just do a coin flip predicting one would get heads and one would get tails (25% chance is pretty good), you each need to run this experiment a minimum of 30 times to get a statistical handle on the consistency of the result.  Then there's making a connection to the toilet bowls.  In the formula for Coriolis sits velocity.  If the velocity is zero, there is no Coriolis.  The water in both the toilet bowl and your pools started at near enough to zero, but both get velocity as they move in toward the drain.  Problem with the toilet is that there is too little time and distance to build that up to any significant degree.  You rightly pointed out that it is more jet and bowl shape dependent.  Your pool had time and enough distance to let that very small Coriolis that had built up with motion, to finally overcome (probably, we don't know until you run 29 more) the other forces possible.  Was it deionized water with no magnetic fields?  I know that would be small at best but an ionic gradient in a field could come near the Coriolis force involved here.

There was never really any doubt about the effect, it can be clearly demonstrated by observing the direction of rotation in atmospheric pressure systems, ocean currents, and the motion of a large pendulums. The reason it's hard (but not impossible) to observe in toilets is due to the size of the atmosphere/oceans vs the size of a toilet/sink. At the toilet scale, random motion becomes the dominant effect.
Having said that it was an elegant and inexpensive experiment that clearly demonstrated the very weak but very real effect. - congrats.

It's hilarious watching people trying to prove one assumption/unproven theory by using another assumption/unproven theory.
What is taught today as "law" is really nothing more than an unproven theory. You'd know that if you cared to read Newton's book of Principia. He himself uses the word "if" a thousand times in that book because he himself was not certain, know why? Because it was a THEORY, not a FACT.
What is currently deemed "Science" like Einstein's theory of relativity and Newton's supposed "law of gravity", are what's truly dubious. Heliocentrists cannot show us a single object massive enough that by virtue of its mass alone causes other smaller masses to stick to or orbit it as they claim happens with the Sun, Moon, Earth, Stars and Planets. If you cannot give me a single practical example of "gravity" smaller than the Earth or the Sun, then it is merely heresay, not science! Other than magnets, there are no objects they can point to to prove their supposed "gravity" that's strong enough to hold people, buildings and the oceans stuck to the underside of a spinning ball-Earth, but weak enough to allow little bugs, birds, and helium balloons to fly away with ease. If there was a magical magnetism that held our feet firm to the underside of a spinning ball, we would feel this magical force every time we lifted our leg, and the force would increase like a magnet the closer our foot was to the ground.
The idea that people are standing, ships are sailing and planes are flying upside down on certain parts of Earth while others tilted at 90 degrees and all other impossible angles is complete absurdity. The idea that a man digging a hole straight down could eventually reach sky on the other side is ludicrous. Common sense tells every free-thinking person correctly that there truly is an "up" and “down” in nature, unlike the "everything is relative" rhetoric of the Newtonian/Einsteinian paradigm.
You jump off a building or cliff and fall down because that's how nature is. Everything that goes up must come down. Gravity is simply density and buoyancy. People argue that things with different densities fall at the same rate through air. However, that is because both items have reached critical density in relation to its medium: air. If you were to change the medium from air to say, water or liquid mercury, the critical density to achieve the same rate of falling would increase significantly. Critical density is directly proportional to the medium density. Thus the denser the medium... The denser the objects would have to be in order to achieve the same rate of falling. A basketball and a rock might fall at the same speed in air. However... Drop them in a thicker medium like water... And they will not fall at the same rate. That is because critical density has not been achieved by both the rock and the basketball, in water as its medium. In a vacuum... Critical density is zero and is the reason why objects of any density fall at exactly the same rate. Any medium denser than a vacuum has a greater critical density than zero... Thus the reason why objects that haven't attained critical density fall slower in certain mediums. Critical density variation is "gravity".
So, an object is dropped from a high altitude, this would not and does not, slow down as it gets closer to Earth. The object is free-falling and accelerating as it falls due to the laws of density, not because some magical force is "pulling" it down. There is more oxygen closer to Earth than say twenty miles up, so how does one propose "gravity" explains this and density does not? Oxygen is a denser gas than nitrogen and the other majority elements in our atmosphere. Where is the "pulling force" pulling the oxygen down? The rate at which objects rise or fall depends on the resistance (or lack thereof) in the medium surrounding.
Examples:
The submarine can use compressed air to ascend in water.
The hot-air-balloon can use hot air to ascend in the atmosphere.
The airplane can use pressure difference across its flying surfaces to gain lift.
There is no pulling. Only falling and rising. No force pulls down.

"Proved" (@4:15) is a pretty strong word (and a rather unscientific one), especially for an experiment with that much mono-method bias and such a low sample size (given limited methodological controls for known effects). I appreciate Dustin's curiosity and zeal, but his emphatic statement (@4:19) that "The Coriolis effect is real," suggests a rather banal research question. Even so, his leap to suggesting that his experiment "proved" that the CE caused the observed effect in the pool (n=3 w/ single apparatus) seems excessive, and it leads me to wonder how well he understands scientific methods, threats to validity, and the epistemology of science.

1. It highly depends on the toilet, most toilets nowdays, have the kind of shape to make the water swirl down. Regardless of the location on planet, if you use one of those toilets, water will always swirl the same way, however it might go smoother in north or south.

2. I've done a test in kitchen sink, well not really a test, just something i have noticed. If i move the tap on LEFT side so water falls against the side of the sink, then it swirls one way, but if i turn tap RIGHT, so that water falls against right side of the sink, then water swirls the other way.
If i turn on both taps (if you have 2) and put them on each side, then water don't swirl at all, it will look like sink is blocked and it starts filling up slowly, because taps will cancel the swirl and make water just pile up.

don't believe me? make a test yourself, but keep in mind that it might not work with every shape of the sink.

Coriolis effect is real, but does NOT determine the direction of rotation of water going down an ordinary drain. The effect on such a small volume of water, over such a short time, compared to other factors, is far too small to determine direction of rotation.

Suppose the rotation shown in the kiddy pool in this video was indeed induced by Coriolis. If so, notice that it was a very weak, very slow rotation, under controlled conditions, compared to what you see in the bathtub.

The Coriolis effect itself isn't controversial - the only question is whether drains go one way up north, and the other way down south. So it's deceptive and/or mis-informative to claim that this experiment proves that Coriolis determines the direction.

I just drained two sinks, side by side, half a meter apart. One rotated thisaway, and the other rotated thataway! (No, they don't straddle the equator.)

But why believe these guys, or me, or anyone else? It's easy to test, for free. Prove it to yourself. Watch a dozen or two sinks drain, and see if they all go the same way round.

Formula at hand, apparent Coriolis acceleration is 2*w*V*sin(lat). Considering a pool, V~10^-2m/s, while w=2pi/86400 1/s, so Ac=1.45*10^-6 sin(lat), consequently Ac(35 ̊) = 8.34 *10^-7 m/s^2
After 60s the Ac would "cause" a lateral speed of 10^-5 m/s, that means a displacement of .5*Ac*t^2 = 1.5*10^-3 m. This why you need a really still water to see the Coriolis effect in a poll.
At few meters from the equator, the effect is so small that the deviation is less than the dimension of a water molecule.

I don't think the science is sound on this one. I really don't believe that the airflow was completely quenched, the pool stand perfectly level, and the valve perfectly situated for uniform opening. Even a slight deviation in the initial conditions would cause the pool to start swirling in one way rather than the other. To acquire evidence that the Coriolis effect on a tiny body of water is significant enough to induce a detectable change in angular momentum would require a far more controlled environment than the one presented in this video.

I have a few issues with your experimental procedure. Mathematically, your pool is not large enough in diameter to exhibit any noticeable effect from the coriolis effect. Second, if your drain is even SLIGHTLY off kilter or off centre, that will influence the spin of the water far more than the rotation of the earth. Any imperfections in the surface of the drain would affect it as well. It's an interesting demonstration, but I think the random imperfections in the sides of the pool and the surfaces of the drain would influence the direction the water goes more than the rotation of the earth.

Suggestion: Set up five pools in identical manners, cover them with fine mesh to prevent air currents or foreign material from affecting the pool, then drain them all simultaneously. additionally, a neutrally buoyant particulate in the water might be a better way of demonstrating the currents, as dripping dye into the water will introduce currents as well. (I noticed in the video, that you introduced the dye in the same direction as you wanted the water to spin).

The Coriolis IS NOT an effect is an acceleration just in the same class as Gravity and Centrifugal. In fact some text call it "Compound Centrifugal". Sometimes are called "Pseudo forces" Herman Weyl "Space Time, Matter

A simpler explanation to the Coriolis effect, visualizing the momenta of individual water particles is conservation of angular momentum:
In the northern hemisphere, everything has a counter-clockwise angular momentum, which gets greater the further from the equator.
When the pool drains, water goes toward the center, decreasing the radius of the center of mass (radially), which decreases the moment of inertia of the water (yes, mass decreases as well, but moment of inertia depends more on radius than mass - I = mr^2)...
So with conservation of angular momentum, we have Iw = Iw. I decreases; w increases. The water in the pool starts spinning faster than it already is from the Earth's spin, and you see it spin.

Your demonstration of opposite flows of sink waters is misleading: Typically the plumbing of these types of double basin sinks are two drainage pipes leading into one. If you have ever filled up one and opened the valve, you will notice that the opposite basin sink begins to fill with some overflow. This incurs the flows to spin counter to each other when the valves are simultaneously engaged.

In addition: One could argue that the experiment is biased by weather conditions: Wind and local humidity. Two similarly shaped sinks with reasonable plumbing should consistently replicate the Coriolis Effect.

Dye spotting can also affect water flow through the Marangoni Effect (Typical food dye is high in propylene glycol concentration). Solid particles such as microbeads, sand, or toilet paper are the typical choice for flow visualization.

Everyone is talking about the synched videos -- which clearly took well-planned shooting AND editing!  -- but NO ONE is commenting on your miraculous data! On how BOTH your videos completely contradict everything we know about the physical world!
      If your northern hemisphere kiddie pool had indeed been affected only by the Coriolis effect, it would have been rotating clockwise as ocean currents in the northern hemisphere do. (The North Atlantic and North Pacific rotate clockwise; South Atlantic and South Pacific rotate counter-clockwise.)
       EVEN IN YOUR OWN ILLUSTRATION at 4:30. If you imagine yourself standing at the edge of that enormous pool in Greenland and then, as you correctly do in the video, rotate the earth toward the east, the water in the pool would appear to be rotating clockwise to you standing next to it.
       Yet your 1.5m pools rotated counter-clockwise in the north, and clockwise in the south.
       And why did you say a hurricane would rotate the same way? Hurricanes are large low pressure systems that work AGAINST gravity and flow "up" (away from the earth's surface) hence rotate the OPPOSITE of the ocean currents which are perpetually pulled DOWN by gravity.
       The other possibility of course is that physics has changed overnight, in which case, you guys will not only win internet video awards, but at least a couple Nobel Prizes!

Something to consider is the way that conservation of angular momentum affects this. I once did a version of this experiment where I showed that an imperceptible initial rotation (which I could induce at will in either direction) would speed-up into a multiple rotation per second vortex, predictably always in the same direction as the initial influence, as the water drained out. I think this happens due to the way that angular momentum is transferred by viscosity in the water as well as being conserved as the radius of rotation decreases (like a figure skater drawing his/her arms in while spinning and speeding up as a result)

This was so funny because I was already subscribed to both of your channels. So I saw these 2 videos show up in the upload feed and watched & enjoyed them. I also posted this comment on the other video xD

The speed of the earth spinning at the equator is 1,600 KPH. A meter is 1/10,000,00 of the distance between the North Pole and the equator. The kiddie pool is 2 meters across. So the difference in speed between the "North" end of the drain and the "South" end of the drain is 2/10,000,000 of about 1,000KPH (due to your latitude). That equals a speed difference between the north point and the south point as twenty centimeters (about 7 inches) PER HOUR. As my analog watch dial is 3cm in diameter, the speed which the hour hand moves around the dial is 10 cm per hour, a rough approximation of the speed of the one of the furthest points from the drain on the pool. The viscosity of water, Brownian motion, and how the drain was made (is it made by the manufacturer to spin?) would completely overwhelm any Coriolis effect that is this small. Even tornadoes are too small to have them spin in any particular direction. Hurricanes are much, much, much larger so the Coriolis effect does indeed make it spin counterclockwise in the Northern Hemisphere. The math first before the experiments begin can show how much trust you can put into the results you see.
EDIT: the Wiki article about the Coriolis Effect had an example of a scientific experiment in 1908 that showed a statistically significant result of CCL draining of a 1.8 meter tub of water with initial conditions similar to what was done in this experiment but under "carefully controlled laboratory conditions", it took over 15 minutes before any rotation occurred, it was done many times, and the results averaged (which to me means that sometimes it did NOT go CCL). Was this experiment done under such exacting standards? I donno.

I like this experiment because it's so fascinating that it doesn't matter whether the pool is tilted or not, the water surface settles to an infinitesimal sector of the Earth's surface area. The molecules of water are so small that it can settle to a nearly perfect sector of the Earth's surface area, allowing the Coriolis effect to take place. Let physics do the work! It never fails!

About the idea of performing this experiment at the equator, this Coriolis effect can be used to locate, over several months of repositioning four separate pools, the exact position of the Earth's equator. However, because space is a continuum, it's practically impossible for a human to place something perfectly on the equator. Therefore, there will always be one side of the pool that has more force being applied and therefore there will always be a predetermined direction. The direction in which the water swirls will never be random for that reason. Come to think of it, is anything random?

Coriolis effect
awesome!

In both videos, at 2:24, you can see why the water rotates the direction it does: The wrinkles in the pool. Destin's has counter-clockwise wrinkles around the drain, and Derek's wrinkles on the outer edge are going clockwise. As the water molecules are pulled toward the center, they run into the wrinkles, which push them to the side, slowly causing rotation in the pool.

Sorry to say, but these would have far, far, faaaaar more effect than the rotation of the earth on this tiny pool. Saying this is caused by the Coriolis effect is like saying the waves in your backyard swimming pool are caused by the moon. It's relevant on totally different scales.

Hey, there! I love your videos and I think you do a terrific job at making us smarter every day.
This synced video thing was an awesome idea. Congrats on that!
However I must disagree with your experimental results on this one. Saying you eliminated all external variables just by using a small vinyl pool is waaaaay far from real, and you know that. Compared to the forces generated by the coriolis effect, which are practically inexistent for such a small mass of water, any wrinkle left on the vinyl or any dissymmetry in the pool's geometry would completely ruin your experiment.
That's why the coriolis effect only applies to really large masses of a fluid, such as seas or the atmosphere. The difference in speed between the north and south ends of your 1m wide pool due to Earth rotation is absolutely negligible. Breathing near the surface of your experiment would have stronger effects.
Anyway, I'm just trying to be constructive. Don't get me wrong. I still love your channel.

1 out of 1 is not good statistics. Repeat 20 times and do a t-test.
AND Even if the probability is found to be statistically significant, it could be due to  minute flaws in the drain hole and not the coriolis effect (which is very small at this scale). So really the same drain assembly would need to be tested in both hemispheres.

You only drained the pool once?  And you call that conclusive?  I thought you took a scientific approach to experiments.  Do it a hundred times.  And for gods sake place a clear plastic casing over the entire pool to prevent any moving air from contacting the surface of the water.
Don't you think it's possible that as you were dropping in the food coloring you may very well have decided the direction of the swirl just from the air you were pushing along the top of the water?   Was it just a coincidence that the swirl happened to go in the same direction that you were circling around the pool?  Maybe that's all it took.  You must repeat under controlled conditions,  where air isn't an issue.   Maybe the coloring itself contributed by the way it was thrown.  Don't use any.  You'll be able to see the direction of the swirl at the last moments of the drainage.

I'm really surprised that the point at which the effect can be seen can't just be handled by defining a Coriolis-Reynolds number.  You get the flow slow enough and the pool large enough and the Coriolis force dominates.  You get similar dimensionless numbers defined in the cases of magnetohydrodynamics (the magnetic Reynolds number) or buoyant flow (the Grashof number).

My take on this ( I would love Destin's thoughts on this):  The water doesn't change it's circular direction, you have just changed your perspective.  Imagine looking at a rotating column of water from the top down and the bottom up.  What really changed was your point of view.

To sync- put SED on the left, VE on the right. drag each slider till you see the toilet frame with the synchronize text on it.  Then start 1 and then the other.  You will see the times off by the amount of time it took you to start the 2nd.  Pause and unpause the first video by this difference and there you go.

To synchronize the 2 videos, open 2 browsers and set them up side by side then set up one of the videos in each browser. Play Destin's video until he finishes his countdown then pause it (so 5,4,3,2,1,pause). Then play Derek's video, when he finishes his countdown hit play on Destin's video (so 5,4,3,2,1,play). The videos should be nicely synchronized.

If the Earth's rotation influenced how the flow responded to the mass perturbation induced by the opened pool valve, I believe this would indicate that the radius of the perturbation (i.e. the valve) must be approximately equal to the pool's Rossby deformation radius (assuming there is no vorticity in the flow at time=0).  Assuming you're at mid-latitudes and using a pool depth of .2m, I'm calculating that the radius of the mass perturbation you would have to induce in order for the flow to be significantly influenced by the Earth's rotation (this is to say, as much as buoyancy) would be around 17km. For perturbations with spatial scales smaller than this, the Coriolis terms in the momentum equation can be safely scaled out. However, if you include the affect of relative vorticity, the deformation radius rapidly shrinks as relative vorticity is increased (an argument sometimes used to explain the genesis of tropical cyclones at low latitudes).  If we consider the possibility that the valve itself induced a relative vorticity in the flow as the water flowed into the valve, through it, and out of the pool, the flow can quickly come into balance between a developing radial pressure gradient force and a reactive centrifugal force above the valve.  This type of balance (cyclostrophic) is much more likely to be achieved on the spatial scales of this experiment. I am therefore wondering whether the observed circulation is actually more appropriately classified as cyclostrophic and not geostrophic.  Did you by any chance repeat the experiment a few times to see if the flow continually favored the same direction of rotation? (P.S.  You have an amazing channel...HUGE fan!!!)

Cool videos but I'm having a bit of a problem with the explanation, surely I'm missing something. What is the frame of reference for the water for its motion around the pole? The videos show the pool moving along the rotation of the earth but from a fixed point relative to the earths rotation. Surely the pool shares the same relative motion as the earth and hence does not seem like it is moving when you are standing on the earth. What frame of reference does the water have? Why would it have a different one than the pool it is in?

How to sync on a Windows PC,
>Open two windows open each video in different windows
>Drag the windows of the video to the right/left edge of the screen, you see a box appear covering half the screen release your mouse and the window should be only covering half the screen.
>Smarter Everyday video should be on the left side
>Start this video at 0:25

One complaint: it seems you only have a sample set of 1. I would speculate that the pools certainly have created a vortex no matter what, the only question is: "in what direction will it rotate?" Given that each pool only has two possible outcomes there are only four possibilities for this experiment: they both drain clockwise, they both drain counterclockwise, they both go in the "correct" direction, or they both go in the "wrong" direction. Basically all I'm saying is that, no matter what, you had a 25% chance of it happening as it did.
